Article.ArticleTitle: Adsorption characteristics of trace levels of bromate in drinking water by modified bamboo-based activated carbons.

AbstractText: This study was undertaken to investigate the adsorption kinetics and isotherms of bromate (BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>) on bamboo charcoals that are activated with nitrogen and water vapor. Bamboo-based activated carbon (AC) was dipped in acid and oxidized in a mixture of potassium permanganate and sulfuric acid. Oxidation treatment considerably improved the physicochemical properties of AC, including purity, pore structure and surface nature, significantly enhancing BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> adsorption capacity. AC with many oxygenated groups and a high mesopore volume exhibited a particularly favorable tendency for BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> adsorption. Its adsorption of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> is best fitted using Langmuir isotherm, and forms a monolayer. A kinetic investigation revealed that the adsorption of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> by the ACs involved chemical sorption and was controlled by intra-particle diffusion. The competitive effects of natural organic matter (NOM) on AC were evaluated, and found to reduce the capacity of carbon to adsorb BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>. Residual dissolved ozone reacted with AC, reducing its capacity to absorb BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>. Proper dosing and staging of the ozonation processes can balance the ozone treatment efficiency, BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> formation, and the subsequent removal of BrO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>.
